Award.AwardTitle: Virtual Faculty Workshops on TUES Project Development and Implementation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION

This Central Resource Project seeks to develop a virtual web-based framework to better prepare current and future TUES principal investigators in the development, implementation, evaluation and dissemination of their projects. The project builds upon the Interactive Web-Based Workshop (IWBW) model developed and used extensively by engineering and computer science NSF Program Directors (PDs) to provide professional development for engineering and computer sciences faculty. Five workshops that have already been tested are being refined for use across other STEM disciplines (these include: Introduction to the TUES Program; Proposal Writing Strategies; Project Evaluation; Making an Impact: Building Transportable Projects; and Broader Impacts and Project Evaluation). Three other topics are also are being considered for future development, including: faculty development for dissemination, project transportability and dissemination, and increasing participation of underrepresented groups.

Each of the Interactive Web-Based Workshops (IWBWs) is 90 minutes long and is being offered multiple times over the course of the two-year project. The workshop sessions are evenly distributed throughout the combined Spring 2013, Fall 2013, and Spring 2014 timeframe. Each workshop involves pre- and post-assignments, discussion communities as well as Q&A opportunities with current NSF PDs during the on-line sessions. The materials for the workshops are being developed by the project team, in collaboration with former and current NSF PDs and leaders in STEM undergraduate education and evaluation.

The project is specifically helping TUES grantees and other science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) faculty at colleges and universities (including community colleges) to better understand how they can: 1) improve existing NSF TUES undergraduate STEM education projects, 2) work with an evaluator to plan and implement effective evaluations that document the impacts of TUES projects, 3) design educational research and development projects with broad impact; including faculty change, dissemination and broadening participation, and 4) develop, create and implement TUES-specific or other undergraduate STEM education projects.


BROADER SIGNIFICANCE

This project is engaging the more than 750 current NSF TUES-funded projects, which represent about 379 institutions, as well as additional faculty members who intend to submit TUES proposals. Special efforts are being conducted to engage STEM faculty from community colleges and from minority-serving institutions (MSIs). Colleges and universities (as well as individual faculty) can participate in one or more workshops - but are being strongly encouraged to participate in all 8 workshops.

The specific resources and products being developed by this project include: eight virtual workshops focused on TUES project development, implementation, and evaluation; a project website, hosting IWBW descriptions and presenters, resources, evaluation instruments, registration, and other project related information; ten on-going virtual focus groups (PI Forums) organized during the TUES PI Conference and facilitated by the project to discuss specific STEM education topics; and an online monthly electronic TUES newsletter, including announcements from projects that are recruiting collaborators, field test sites, or faculty workshop participants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary

The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS, Louisiana State University (LSU), and Higher Education Services (HES), Inc. implemented a five-year National Science Foundation (NSF) TUES Central Resource project to evaluate the effectiveness of a virtual format to prepare both current and prospective grantees in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) undergraduate education programs to better develop, implement, evaluate, and disseminate their projects. 

Intellectual Merit

This project provided 5 Interactive Web-Based Workshops (IWBW), including (a) Proposal Strategies, (b) Project Evaluation, (c) Broader Impacts, (d) Goals and Expected Outcomes, and (e) Impact and Transportability. Each virtual workshop session consisted of an introduction to the topic by an online workshop leader, followed by a sequence of on on-site interactive group activities led by a campus facilitator. These on-site activities were designed to engage the participants in a collaborative learning process where they could:

•    recall their current understanding of the topic,
•    share ideas with one or two other participants, and
•    participate in a brief local discussion.

Following these local discussions, selected sites were asked to share some ideas that they discussed with the entire virtual group. Subsequent to these reports, the online workshop leaders shared their ideas and insights with the group. Concluding local activities included a local group discussion to the workshop focus.

Thus, faculty and staff participated in the IWBW as a group on their campus. Volunteer campus facilitator assisted with locating campus space, workshop sign-up, on-site workshop activities, and evaluation.

This project builds upon the IWBW model developed and used extensively by engineering and computer science NSF Program Directors (PDs), prior to this project. For this project, the IWBWs learning goals, objectives, and activities were revised by a team of seven external consultants representing six different STEM disciplines from seven different institutions, all former Division of Undergraduate Education (DUE) PDs.

More details on the project can be located on the website at http://ehrweb01.aaas.org/stem-iwbw/

Broader Impacts

A total of 47 IWBWs were presented, including:

***16 IWBWs in March – April 2013;

***10 IWBWs in January 2014;

***11 IWBWs in October-November 2014;

***5 IWBWs in September – October 2015; and

***5 IWBW in November/December 2016.

Between 2013 and 2016, one-thousand-four-hundred-and-seventeen (1,417) participants registered for one or more of the 47 IWBWs. Faculty or staff participated as a group on their campus in one or more of the 5 IWBWS.  Also, about 421 faculty and staff from 308 colleges and universities registered to serve as campus facilitators for one or more of 47 IWBWs.

Overall, 98 (6.6%) of the 1,417 IWBW registrants were from community colleges.

Also with NSF Program Directors, 26 Improving Undergraduate Education (IUSE) proposal preparation webinars were conducted between 2013 and 2016. Overall, 3,692 faculty and staff from 778 colleges and universities and other institutions registered for the 26 IUSE webinars.

In 2015, (a) 109 two-year colleges participated in the IUSE webinar for community colleges; (b) 100 participants registered for the IUSE workshops for geosciences; and (c) 199 participants registered for the IUSE workshop for preservice STEM educators.

An external evaluation for each of the 5 IWBW topics was conducted from January to November 2014, based on feedback provided by participants on the registration form (entry survey) and post-workshop surveys. A summary of the external evaluation reports indicates the following:

A. Demographics

***Nearly all participants were from universities and colleges.

***Attendees were primarily from engineering and biology but attendees overall represented most science and engineering fields.

***Most of the workshop participants were White/Caucasian or Asian.

***Less than 10% of attendees were Black or Native American.

***Only about 5% of attendees at any workshop reported having a disability.

B. NSF/IUSE experience

***Attendees included a mix of those who have/have not received funding but nearly all attendees were new to the IUSE program.

***Many attendees had attended NSF or non-NSF funding workshops.

***About half of the attendees read the IUSE request for proposals before participating in the IWBW.

C. Workshop impacts

***Participants rated the workshop components very positively (technology, facilitators, and activities). On a 4 point scale with 4 being the highest rating, ratings ranged from 3.2 to 3.7.

***At the end of the workshop, participants rated their skills/knowledge on the workshop topics very positively, expressing confidence that they could complete key tasks related to the workshop topics. On a 5 point scale with 5 being the highest rating, ratings ranged from 4.3 to 4.7.

***Percentages of participants planning to submit a proposal to IUSE varied from workshop to workshop but, in each workshop, there was a sizeable core group with plans to use the information in preparing an IUSE proposal or other proposal. Depending on the workshop, 36% to 49% of the respondents planned to submit a proposal to the NSF IUSE program; and 49% to 64% planned to apply for other funding.
